scenes.plot_segment: A montage of scenes from previous episodes is shown. Various characters discuss romantic feelings and relationships, including someone expressing difficulty confessing feelings to a roommate, another character suggesting asking her out, and a conversation about someone being 'off the market.' There are references to a secret relationship between Meredith and an attending, concerns about favoritism, and warnings about the consequences if Meredith receives special treatment. Bailey threatens to keep Meredith out of the OR if she is favored. These scenes summarize ongoing storylines and character dynamics.

Meredith narrates about the exhaustion of being an intern and how it's not just the job that keeps them up at night. In the early morning, Meredith urges someone to leave her bed before her roommates see. There is playful banter about who was responsible for the noise the previous night. Roommates speculate about Meredith's sex life and joke about her having a long day at work. The group discusses the possibility that Meredith is sleeping with their boss, with some denying it and others questioning why she would keep it a secret. Meredith deflects questions about her sex life and urges everyone to leave for work.

At the hospital, Meredith worries about her roommates finding out about her relationship with Dr. Shepherd. She expresses concern about being perceived as getting special treatment. Bailey assigns O'Malley, Yang, and Karev to the clinic, and tells Izzie she will be working with her. Bailey gives Meredith a list of tasks, including a consult for a girl with fever and abdominal pain, and other patient responsibilities. Bailey warns Meredith to get started quickly.

Meredith examines a young woman named Claire who has a fever and abdominal pain. Claire's mother and another woman discuss her recent trip to Mexico and weight loss. Claire resists an exam, but Meredith insists. Meanwhile, a man named Digby Owens arrives for an appointment, but is found to be bleeding from a gunshot wound. He explains his friend shot him as a favor, and he likes the scars. The staff prepares to treat his injury.

Digby Owens discusses his philosophy about pain and commitment, referencing his wrestling background. Another character jokes about men in tights. A character with the flu comments on the irony. Meredith examines Claire and discovers recent surgical scars. Claire asks Meredith not to tell her parents. Meredith questions Claire about the surgery, and Claire admits to having it done in Mexico.

A young girl named Jamie is discussed with her parents, who describe her worsening foot twitching and previous CT scan showing a brain abnormality. Meredith reassures the parents and says she will bring in Dr. Shepherd, the brain specialist. The parents ask if Dr. Shepherd is good, and Meredith responds affirmatively.

A patient who swallowed keys is prepped for a bronchoscopy. An intern is given the opportunity to perform the procedure alone. Meredith reports to Bailey about her pit patient, Claire, who is febrile with peritoneal signs and has had possible illegal surgery in Mexico. Bailey instructs Meredith to handle additional tasks and to document patient information. Another character with the flu is told to go home but refuses.

Two interns discuss Meredith's relationship with Dr. Shepherd and the risks it poses to their careers. One expresses concern that Shepherd is taking advantage of Meredith, while another points out that it did not sound non-consensual. The group debates the implications of sleeping with an attending.

A staff member delivers Jamie's CT scans to a doctor. Two characters comment on the anesthesiologist, Dr. Taylor, possibly smelling of alcohol, but dismiss concerns as long as he can do his job. In the OR, Dr. Shepherd is informed about Jamie's admission and her symptoms. He requests new scans, as the old ones are three months outdated. Meredith agrees to order them.

A group of doctors discuss Digby Owens' previous gunshot wound and his ethos about pain. They recognize him from a previous visit. Meredith brings Claire's CT scans to Bailey, who identifies that Claire has had a gastric bypass, a procedure usually reserved for obese patients. Claire's mother is shocked, and Bailey explains the risks and complications. Claire's parents agree to surgery to reverse the bypass, but Claire protests, saying she would rather be thin. Bailey insists the choice is not up to her.

Dr. Shepherd explains to Jamie's parents that she has Rasmussen's encephalitis, which has worsened since her last scan. He says the only treatment is to remove the diseased half of her brain, but because Jamie is young, her brain can compensate. The parents are shocked, but Dr. Shepherd reassures them that surgery could save her life. Another doctor is invited to scrub in on the hemispherectomy if the parents consent.

An intern excitedly tells the group about scrubbing in on the hemispherectomy. The group discusses Meredith's relationship with Dr. Shepherd, with some expressing surprise and others admitting they already knew. They joke about the effects of sex all night and debate whether Meredith is getting special treatment. One intern expresses frustration about not being more upset. Another intern asks about Dr. Taylor's possible drinking at work, but the group is hesitant to act.

Digby Owens discusses his scars and pain tolerance with the doctors. He feels dizzy from blood loss. Another character encourages him to make time for wrestling. In surgery, the team works on Claire's bowel, which is full of adhesions from the abscess. Bailey tells Meredith to pick up extra work in the clinic due to Cristina's illness. Meredith and Bailey have a tense exchange about Meredith's choices outside the hospital. Bailey warns Meredith about the consequences of her actions.

In the OR, Bailey instructs Meredith on repairing an organ. Later, a doctor thanks another for the opportunity to scrub in on a procedure. A staff member brings coffee and a crossword to Dr. Taylor, who is preparing for a long day. Jamie is prepared for anesthesia. Meredith and another doctor notice the smell of alcohol and confront Dr. Taylor, who denies drinking. An argument ensues, and George is told to leave the OR. Dr. Shepherd warns Dr. Taylor to be ready.

A couple argues about their relationship while a doctor prepares to remove swallowed keys from the man. The woman accuses the man of being manipulative and needy. The procedure is performed successfully. The doctor advises the woman to leave for her own sake. She jokes that he will never find where she parked the car.

Bailey tells Meredith to inform Claire's parents about her condition before showering. Meredith and another intern discuss the unpleasant smell from surgery. The group jokes about karma and Meredith's luck with surgeries. Bailey asks which intern is available for Dr. Shepherd's surgery. Cristina insists she is healthy enough, but Bailey chooses Meredith. Cristina accuses Meredith of getting special treatment due to her relationship with Dr. Shepherd.

A doctor reviews Digby's lab results and finds a high white blood cell count, indicating infection. The team investigates possible sources, and Digby reveals a new tattoo on his calf, which is infected. The infection is worsened by the gunshot wound. Digby is sent to the ICU for antibiotics.

In the OR, Dr. Shepherd and the team begin Jamie's hemispherectomy. Dr. Taylor, the anesthesiologist, is found asleep during surgery, causing Jamie to begin waking up. The team quickly intervenes, and Dr. Taylor is replaced. Dr. Shepherd orders him to leave and get it together.
Digby goes into multisystem organ failure due to sepsis. The medical team attempts to stabilize him with medication and defibrillation, but he loses his pulse. The team works to revive him.

The surgical team completes Jamie's hemispherectomy, packing the cavity to prevent hemorrhaging. Cristina is asked to explain the procedure, and she describes how cerebrospinal fluid will fill the cavity. The team is allowed to close up. Cristina and another intern reflect on the intensity of the surgery and their exhaustion.

George apologizes to Dr. Taylor for confronting him about drinking. Dr. Taylor admits he was out of line and says he should have taken responsibility. He tells George he did the right thing, regardless of the code among doctors.
Dr. Shepherd and another doctor discuss Meredith, with Shepherd insisting he does not favor her and that she is a great intern. They prepare to tell Jamie's parents about her successful surgery.

Meredith tells Claire that the bypass was reversed but she will have lifelong nutritional problems. Claire's parents are upset, and Meredith tells Claire's mother that Claire is trying to please her. Meredith arranges for social services to help Claire, telling her that life should not be this hard.
Digby dies from sepsis. Another character reflects on meeting him and the people from back home. The time of death is called.

Late at night, Meredith finds Izzie baking a cake. Izzie confronts Meredith about her relationship with Dr. Shepherd, pointing out Meredith's privileges and questioning her choices. Izzie accuses Meredith of falling for him, which Meredith denies. They joke about the situation and discuss the details of Meredith's relationship.

Meredith narrates about pain and why people might seek it out. Cristina and another character discuss the aftermath of the day. Meredith and Dr. Shepherd consider sleeping, reflecting on the saying about hitting oneself with a hammer because it feels good when you stop.
